sen.j: 奨学院（しょうがくいん）とは、平安時代の大学別曹の一。
sen.e: Shogakuin was one of the Daigakubesso in the Heian period.
Shogakuin was one of the Daigakubesso in the Heian period.
Shogakuin was one of the Daigaku-besso in the Heian period.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 大学別曹とは、平安時代の貴族（公家）の教育機関である。
sen.e: "Daigakubesso" were the academic facilities for nobles in the Heian Period.
"Daigakubesso" were the academic facilities for nobles in the Heian Period.
Daigaku-besso were the academic facilities for nobles in the Heian period.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 奨学院は、881年（元慶5年）、在原行平が創設した。
sen.e: Shogakuin was established by ARIWARA no Yukihira in 881.
Shogakuin was established by ARIWARA no Yukihira in 881.

sen.j: 奨学院の位置は左京三条、大学寮の南、勧学院の西で、現在の京都府京都市中京区西ノ京南聖町。
sen.e: It was located at Sakyo Sanjo at the south of Daikgakuryo (the government facility to educate students-to-be-bureaucrats) and at the west of Kangakuin (the Fujiwara family's academic facility), where the address is now Nishinokyo Nansei Cho, Nakagyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

It was located at Sakyo Sanjo to the south of Daikgakuryo (the government facility to educate students who would later become bureaucrats) and to the west of Kangakuin (the Fujiwara family's academic facility), and the address is now Nishinokyo Nansei Cho, Nakagyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

It was located at Sakyo Sanjo to the south of Daigaku-ryo (the government facility to educate students who would later become bureaucrats) and to the west of Kangakuin (the Fujiwara family's academic facility), and the address is now Nishinokyo Nansei-cho, Nakagyo-ku Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 奨学院には、皇親、諸王、皇別氏族（源氏・平氏・在原氏など）一族の子弟が寄宿し、大学寮に通った。
sen.e: Sons of the Imperial Family members, local lords, and clans descended from the Imperial families (the Minamoto clan, the Taira clan, and Ariwara clan) lived in Shogakuin to attend classes at Daigakuryo.

Sons of the Imperial Family members, local lords, and clans descended from the Imperial families (the Minamoto clan, the Taira clan, and Ariwara clan) lived in Shogakuin to attend classes at Daigakuryo.

Sons of the Imperial Family members, local lords, and clans descended from the Imperial families (the Minamoto clan, the Taira clan, and Ariwara clan, and so on) lived in Shogakuin to attend classes at Daigaku-ryo.

sen.j: 900年（昌泰3年）には大学寮南曹として公認され、勧学院と並び「南曹の二窓」と称された。
sen.e: It was officially recognized as Daigakuryo Nanso (one of the Daigakubesso located at the south of Daigakuryo) in 900, and was called "Nanso no Niso" (two academies at the south) along with Kangakuin.
It was officially recognized as Daigakuryo Nanso (one of the Daigakubesso located to the south of Daigakuryo) in 900, and was called "Nanso no Niso" (two academies to the south) along with Kangakuin.

It was officially recognized as Daigaku-ryo Nanso (one of the Daigaku-besso located to the south of Daigaku-ryo) in 900, and was called 'Nanso no Niso' (two academies to the south) along with Kangakuin.

sen.j: 奨学院の運営は勧学院に倣い、別当（校長にあたる）、学頭（学生の首席）などの役職が置かれた。
sen.e: Shogakuin had official posts such as Betto (the principal) and Gakuto (the top student) following the examples of Kangakuin.
Shogakuin had official posts such as Betto (the principal) and Gakuto (the top student) following the example of Kangakuin.

sen.j: 大学別曹は、貴族の衰勢と共に衰微する。
sen.e: The Daigakubesso lost their power as the aristocracy deteriorated.
The Daigakubesso lost their power as the strength of the aristocracy waned.
The Daigakubesso lost their power as the strength of the aristocracy waned.

sen.j: 平安時代末期の12世紀頃には、奨学院も他の大学別曹と同様、衰微した。
sen.e: In the twelfth century, at the end of the Heian period, Shogakuin declined along with other Daigakubesso.
In the twelfth century, at the end of the Heian period, Shogakuin declined along with other Daigakubesso.
In the twelfth century, at the end of the Heian period, Shogakuin declined along with other Daigaku-besso.

sen.j: その後も奨学院別当職は、名誉職として残る。
sen.e: After that, only Shogakuin Bettoshoku (office of the Betto of Shogakuin) survived as an honorary post.
After that, only the Shogakuin Bettoshoku (office of the Betto of Shogakuin) survived as an honorary post.

sen.j: 奨学院別当職は、源氏長者が兼務する慣例となり、結果として村上源氏の者が淳和院別当職と共に世襲した。
sen.e: It became a customary practice that Genji no Choja (chief of Genji) took the office as an additional post, and eventually members of Murakami-Genji (one of Minamoto clans) held Shogakuin Bettoshoku and Junnain (the detached palace of Emperor Junna) Bettoshoku by succession.

It became a customary practice that Genji no Choja (chief of the Genji) took the office as an additional post, and eventually members of the Murakami-Genji (one of the Minamoto clans) held Shogakuin Bettoshoku and Junnain (the detached palace of Emperor Junna) Bettoshoku by succession.

It became a customary practice that Genji choja (the top of the Minamoto clan) took the office as an additional post, and eventually members of the Murakami-Genji (Minamoto clan) held Shogakuin Bettoshoku and Junnain (the detached palace of Emperor Junna) Bettoshoku by succession.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: のちに足利義満が清和源氏として初めて源氏長者になり両院別当を兼ね、以後もしばしば源氏長者になった足利氏征夷大将軍が兼務した。
sen.e: Later Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA became the first Genji no Choja as Seiwa-Genji (one of Minamoto clans) to succeed the Bettoshoku of both Shogakuin and Junnain, and after that Seii taishogun Ashikaga (the Shogun in the Muromachi period) became Genji no Choja many times to hold these two offices.

Later Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA became the first Genji no Choja as Seiwa-Genji (another of the Minamoto clans) to succeed the Bettoshoku of both Shogakuin and Junnain, and after that Seii taishogun Ashikaga (the Shogun in the Muromachi period) became Genji no Choja many times, holding both of these offices.

Later Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA became the first Genji Choja as Seiwa-Genji (Minamoto clan) to succeed the Bettoshoku of both Shogakuin and Junnain, and after that Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Ashikaga clan (shogun family in the Muromachi period) became Genji Choja many times, holding both of these offices.
sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。"Seii taishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians, great, unifying leader)"→"Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")"に変更しました。

sen.j: 徳川幕府を開いた徳川家康もこれに倣い、徳川秀忠を除く歴代将軍が源氏長者となったため、幕末まで将軍による源氏長者・奨学院別当職・淳和院別当職の世襲が続いた。
sen.e: Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, the founder of the Tokugawa Shogunate, followed suit, and the successive shogun became Genji no Choja except for Hidetada TOKUGAWA to succeed Shogakuin Bettoshoku and Junnain Bettoshoku until the end of the Edo Period.

Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, the founder of the Tokugawa Shogunate, followed suit, and each successive shogun became Genji no Choja except for Hidetada TOKUGAWA and succeeded to the offices of Shogakuin Bettoshoku and Junnain Bettoshoku until the end of the Edo Period.
